data.text: Contents
Introduction

The increasing number of emergency tracheostomies and demand for tracheostomies in the ICU setting has led to an increased number of patients being nursed on the wards with tracheostomies and laryngectomies.

There are increasingly more patients living in the community with a tracheostomy or laryngectomy, who may require admission to the hospital for management and treatment of conditions other than those related to their airway. Admission to the hospital may mean that they are unable to manage their airway in their usual way, and in general they should be cared for in the same way as all other laryngectomy or tracheostomy patients.
The aim of the tracheostomy tube is to:
Maintain a patent airway
Reduce damage to the larynx, mouth or nose through prolonged endotracheal intubation
Decrease the anatomical dead space by approximately 150mL, therefore decreasing airway resistance
Improve oral hygiene and patient comfort
Provide access for suctioning of the airway
Prevent gross aspiration of oral secretions to the lungs
Scope

The aim of this policy is to provide health care professionals working at Broomfield Hospital with practical information on the safe, appropriate management of an adult patient with a front of neck airway (tracheostomy and laryngectomy) in the ward environment. These patients are at high risk of adverse events and need specific equipment and specially trained staff to care for them.

It is vital that everybody who is involved with the care of a patient with a front of neck airway knows whether the patient has had a tracheostomy or a laryngectomy performed  and  the dates of  the  operations.  This is  necessary  for  general  and emergency management. Therefore, the tracheostomy or laryngectomy notification signs as appropriate should be placed above the patient's bedhead in full view (see appendices 1 and 2).
All adult patients with a front of neck airway (tracheostomy or laryngectomy) should be nursed on the following designated wards only: -
Accident and Emergency, GICU, Burns ICU, GHDU, Theatre Recovery, Billericay, Stock, Burns Adult Ward, Frailty Ward.

It is recognised that there is an increasing number of patients requiring tracheostomy in critical care, where care is directed by the intensive care team. Additional input will be sought by the tracheostomy team as required and will include Speech and Language Therapy, Physiotherapy, Dietetics and ENT.

The tracheostomy team should be notified as soon as possible when such a patient is admitted, or if there are any concerns, on bleep number #6555 2244 (Mon-Fri) or via the on-call physiotherapist (Sat-Sun).

For patients with front of neck airways who are preparing to be discharged home or to a care home for the first time, it is possible for family/ carers to look after the patient's airway on the ward provided they have undergone training and competency sign off (see Appendices 10 and 11) by airway competent staff.

For patients admitted from home/ a care home with a front of neck airway, it is possible for family/ carers to look after the patient's airway on the ward as long as a risk assessment has been completed and an individualised care plan is formalised. The family member/ carer should not take the place of an airway competent nurse.
Definitions

table_items.text: A tracheostomy is an opening into the anterior wall of the trachea and is used to facilitate ventilation, protect the lungs against gross aspiration or as a port for suctioning. It may be temporary or permanent depending on the patient's diagnosis. The tracheostomy may be formed as an elective or emergency procedure and it may be performed surgically or percutaneously. The tube facilitates airflow to the trachea and lungs directly, bypassing the nose, pharynx and larynx if the tracheostomy tube cuff is inflated. Alternatively, the patient may breathe through the tube and their upper airway if the tracheostomy cuff is deflated.

A laryngectomy involves removal of the larynx (voicebox) and terminalisation of the trachea at the neck, called an “end tracheostome”. There is no potential for the patient to breathe through their upper airway following a laryngectomy operation.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Committee responsibilities
Tracheostomy Team
To ensure all policies, standard operating procedures and guidelines relating to the care of adult patients with front of neck airways meet the appropriate standards and are well maintained.
Individual responsibilities
Staff caring for patients with front of neck airways

All staff should meet tracheostomy training and competency requirements (see 5.2 below), be aware of and comply with the processes outlined in this policy. They also should ensure that the incident reporting policy and procedure is followed in the event of deviation from this policy.
Staffing and training requirements

A patient with a front of neck airway is exposed to many potential risks and complications and therefore is usually more dependent on nursing care than other patients. This dependence should be reflected in the numbers of nurses on the ward.

Access to work-based education and training is essential for ward and department staff in order to ensure that they are competent to assess and manage acutely ill patients who are at risk of deterioration. All staff caring for patients with tracheostomies must first attend formal in-house tracheostomy training. This is followed by the staff member completing the Tracheostomy Competence document (see Appendix 9) and being signed off by a tracheostomy competent staff member every 2 years.

Individualised nursing care must be given to each patient with a tracheostomy. A tracheostomy specific nursing care plan must be implemented and updated daily by the health care professional caring for the patient. The planning of care for each patient should involve communication with all members of the multidisciplinary team as well as the patient.

It is essential that each person caring for a patient with a tracheostomy has received the correct training and is competent. The expected level of individual competency can be identified in the MSE general technical competency framework which is accessible on the intranet.
Essential equipment and signage
Bed head signage
Appropriate Bed head signs must be in place for all patients with a front of neck airway. There should be 2 signs placed above the bed head in full view: -

These signs should be attached to the foot of the bed for all patients in transit. The full National Tracheostomy Safety Project Emergency algorithms for Tracheostomy and Laryngectomy should be attached to the difficult airway trolley for each appropriate ward area. See Appendices 4 and 5 for these documents.
Blue box and airway care chart

The availability of equipment at the bedside is imperative to save the patient's life should an emergency occur, for example a blocked tube. The Blue Box is a portable case which contains essential first line equipment for emergency situations. A fully stocked patient specific Blue Box must be positioned on top of the tracheostomy trolley for all patients with front of neck airways. The patient's Blue Box must stay with them at all times, e.g. during transit. The equipment checklist (see Appendix 6) should be completed once on each shift and any equipment, once used, should be replaced immediately. The Airway care chart (Appendix 7) should be updated after all tracheostomy related interventions e g suction.
Tracheostomy passport

Each patient who has a tracheostomy needs a tracheostomy passport. This important document details the date and reason why the patient has a tracheostomy, if they have a patent upper airway and it provides a history of tube changes thereby improving communication and facilitating good airway care. The tracheostomy passport is completed by the team looking after the patient at the time of the tracheostomy operation and on every subsequent tube change. Whilst the patient is in hospital the tracheostomy passport is placed in the emergency Blue Box and it is issued to the patient when they are discharged into the community. The patient is asked to bring the passport in with them on subsequent hospital admissions.
Tracheostomy tube types

Every patient with a new tracheostomy should have a double lumen tracheostomy tube i.e. a tracheostomy tube with a removable inner cannula in place. If a patient is transferred from another hospital with a single lumen tracheostomy tube, this should be changed to a double lumen tube as soon as safely possible*. There are many types and makes of tubes available; the main tube used within Broomfield Hospital is the Kapitex Tracoetwist Plus™. The tube is made from polyurethane, which is light and flexible and becomes supple at body temperature. Tracheostomy tubes can be of standard length or longer length e.g. tracoetwist Plus™.
*Some patients living in the community with long term tracheostomy may have a single lumen silver tube in place. In these patients it is usually appropriate to leave this in situ.

Patients with laryngectomy generally do not have a tracheostomy tube in place beyond the first 2 – 3 days post op. Instead, they may wear a laryngectomy tube, Buchannan bib, stoma button or heat and moisture exchanger mounted on a baseplate depending on the shape of their stoma and their personal preference.

Tracoetwist Plus™ has a unique swivelling neck plate, which reduces pressure at the distal end of the tube, where digging into the tracheal mucosa can occur. This allows the patient to turn their head freely and comfortably in all directions.

The fenestrated tube comes with two inner cannulae, one plain and one fenestrated. An unfenestrated tube comes with two plain inner cannulae. The inner cannulae are inserted using a twist-lock mechanism providing confidence that the tube is securely in place.

Tracoetwist Plus™ tubes can either be cuffed or uncuffed. By adding air into the pilot balloon, it will inflate the cuff so the patient's only way of breathing is via the tracheostomy tube. This is necessary for mechanical ventilation or for protection of the airway against gross aspiration.

For a fenestrated tube, the fenestrations on the outer tracheostomy tube are multiple small holes. This helps reduce the risks of granulated tissue entering the airway and suction catheters penetrating the tracheal wall.

The Tracoetwist Plus™ comes in a range of sizes (7-10). Within the Trust, the most commonly used sizes are 7 and  All tubes have additional cannulae either plain, fenestrated or with built in speaking valves. Always check which tube the patient has in, the size is marked on the flange. Check which inner cannula the patient has in; white (plain) or blue (fenestrated). Check if it is a cuffed or uncuffed tube; Is a pilot balloon present?

Some Tracoe twist™ tubes have a subglottic suction port facility. This is an extra port which enables removal of pooled secretions from above the inflated cuff with a syringe. The recommended frequency of secretion removal is every 4 hours.
Tracheostomy tube parts

data.url: 05002 Care of adults with front of neck airways 5.0.003.png

data.text: Humidification

The normal mechanisms of warming, moistening and filtering inspired air by the ciliated epithelial cells in the nose and upper airways are bypassed when a tracheostomy or laryngectomy is present. This leaves patients prone to atelectasis and infection. Inhaling dry air leads to paralysis of cilia, dessication of mucus and physiological changes to the tracheal mucosa. Scabs and crusts form in the airway which are difficult to cough up or suction out and may obstruct the tracheostomy tube. Humidification is therefore an important aspect of tracheostomy and laryngectomy care. If it is assessed and delivered appropriately then the need for suctioning may be reduced. The method used for humidification can be altered as the patient's condition changes. Firstly, always ensure a patient is systemically well hydrated.
Artificial humidification increases the moisture content of inspired air to:-
Prevent drying of the tracheal mucosa and interruption of the mucociliary transport process
Loosen thick tenacious secretions and so easing secretion removal/ expectoration
Prevent encrustation or blocking of the tube
ALL PATIENTS WITH FRONT OF NECK AIRWAYS SHOULD HAVE HUMIDIFICATION IN PLACE. PATIENTS WITH LARYNGECTOMY SHOULD HAVE ACTIVE (HEATED) HUMIDIFICATION FOR AT LEAST  HOURS POST OP.
Some common methods of artificial humidification are:

8.3.1 A heat and moisture exchange device (HME device), known as a “Swedish Nose” (a condenser humidifier that fits over the tracheostomy tube and acts as an artificial nose, recycling exhaled heat and moisture). Caution should be taken with those patients who have copious amounts of secretions since the HME may become blocked. Therefore, all HME devices should be observed regularly for blockage by secretions or over-saturation and changed when these are in evidence. All HME devices should be changed at least daily. The Swedish nose is removed when giving alternative methods of humidification (see below).

data.url: 05002 Care of adults with front of neck airways 5.0.005.png

data.text: 8.3.2 Active (heated) humidification - A sterile, closed circuit heated water system and wide bore tubing attached to a tracheostomy mask. The humidification dome, circuit and mask should be changed every  days. Optiflow (Fisher and Paykel) is a commonly used method of providing heated humification in Broomfield Hospital.

8.3.3 Saline nebulisers – 5ml 0.9% normal saline connected to normal gas source flowing at 6-8 litres/minute, delivered using a tracheostomy mask. Saline nebulisers are recommended 4-6 hourly in addition to other methods of humidification. The nebuliser should be rinsed in sterile water and dried thoroughly after each treatment.

8.3.4 ENT “Bibs”, otherwise known as ‘Buchanan Bibs,' can be placed over tracheostomy tubes or, more commonly, are used for the end tracheostome for patients who have had laryngectomy. Patients should wash these daily after use and lay flat to dry.

data.url: 05002 Care of adults with front of neck airways 5.0.006.png

data.text: Tracheal suctioning
It is important that all health professionals who come into contact with tracheostomised patients know the reasons for, and the complications of, tracheal suction.
Suctioning should be performed and documented on the tracheostomy care chart (see Appendix 7) as often as necessary based on repeated assessment of the patient's respiratory function.
Each patient needs individual assessment and constant re-assessment to ascertain the frequency of suctioning required. Newly tracheostomised patients commonly require more frequent suction.
Suction is indicated if any of the following are noted: -
Crackles audible from the bedside (noisy or moist respirations)
Shallow respirations or an irregular breathing pattern
Increased breathlessness
The patient becoming restless and/or anxious
The patient is coughing but not clearing their secretions
Reducing oxygen saturation or cyanosis
Suction pressure

The lowest possible vacuum pressure should be used during suction to reduce complications, including atelectasis. However, the pressure should be sufficient to be effective in removing secretions. Recommended suction pressure is 20Kpa and the maximum vacuum pressure should be  kPa (150 mmHg).

Suction catheters with fingertip control and side-eye ports are essential for this procedure to minimise tracheal mucosa damage. The outer diameter of the suction catheter should be no greater than half the size of the inner diameter of the tracheostomy tube. As a guide see table 1 below.
Table 1- Recommended suction catheter size for tracheostomy tubes

table_items.text: I.D. Internal Diameter F.G. French Gauge E.D. External Diameter

data.text: Equipment needed for suction
A functional suction unit (wall source or portable)
Suction tubing (labelled with date/ change every  hours)
Sterile catheters or closed system suction catheter (appropriate size)
Disposable gloves, apron and eye protection
Sterile normal saline 0.9% ampoules
Oxygen therapy – wall flow meter and tracheostomy mask
Bottled water (labelled “for cleaning suction tubing” with opening date)
Yankauer suction catheter
Protective eye wear
Pulse oximeter
Suction technique
Never suction a patient with a fenestrated tracheostomy tube with the fenestrated inner cannula in situ, it is difficult to pass the catheter and may result in trauma to the tracheal mucosa.
Wash hands and put on a disposable apron and gloves
Explain the procedure to the patient and preoxygenate as necessary
Wear clean gloves and protective eyewear throughout the procedure
Turn on the suction apparatus and attach a sterile catheter. The vacuum pressure should be no more than 20 – 25 kPa (100-150 mmHg)
Put a clean, disposable glove onto the dominant hand and for open suction avoid touching anything with it except for the sterile catheter
With the suction port uncovered i.e., with no suction, introduce the catheter gently into the tracheostomy tube to about 1/3 of the catheter's length or until the patient coughs
Withdraw the tip of the catheter approximately 0.5 cm then apply suction, withdraw the catheter slowly with continuous suction, out of the tracheostomy tube. Do not suction for more than 15 seconds
Release the suction, remove the catheter and glove and discard into an orange clinical waste bag
If the patient is requiring oxygen, re-apply the oxygen supply immediately
Using a fresh, clean glove and new sterile catheter repeat the above steps as indicated until the secretions are cleared and the patient is breathing comfortably

NB. In an acute situation only, where the tube is at risk of blocking and/or the secretions are pluggy and tenacious, a small amount of sterile 0.9% normal saline may be used to aid clearance of secretions by initiating a cough. A competent person should instil 2 – 5 mls of sterile 0.9% normal saline into the tracheostomy tube immediately prior to suctioning.

For closed system suction gently introduce the catheter into the airway using the bag covering the catheter and apply suction, usually by pushing the suction button, and maintaining suction as you withdraw the catheter. Clean the catheter with sterile saline after every use.
Record the intervention on the tracheostomy care chart (see Appendix 7)
Complications of suctioning
9.9.1 Hypoxia has been documented as an adverse effect of airway suction in many studies. This is minimised by adopting a good suction technique.

9.9.2 Cardiac arrhythmias can occur, usually as a result of vagal stimulation. Bradycardia can also occur as a result of vagal stimulation. Pre-oxygenation may reduce the incidence of these from occurring.

9.9.3 Trauma to the tracheal mucosa - Ulceration and necrosis of the tracheal mucosa can be reduced by avoiding excessive suctioning, using the correct type and size of catheter and adopting a good technique.
9.9.4 Anxiety and discomfort is experienced by many patients during suctioning. Adequate explanation and reassurance should be routine prior to and during suction.
9.9.5 Infection - Repeated suctioning may cause tracheal mucosal trauma, this in turn leads to an increased risk of infection. Suction should be performed only when indicated and not routinely.
Infection prevention
Alcohol gel +/- hand washing is essential both before and after all procedures.

Gloves  must be worn and contaminated gloves must be changed between procedures. Sterile gloves must be worn for changing tracheostomy tubes. For suctioning the gloves may be clean rather than sterile.
Aprons  should be worn at all times and changed between procedures and patients.
Eye protection should be worn for all aerosol generating procedures including suction, dressing or tube changes or at any time when there is a risk of coughing secretions over the caregiver
Patients with resistant infections should be nursed in a side room on advice of the Infection Prevention team.
Cleaning the inner cannula of tracheostomy tubes

The tracheostomy inner cannula must be assessed regularly (2 - 6 hourly) to ensure it does not become blocked with secretions. The frequency with which cleaning is required will vary widely between patients.
The factors that should be considered are:
Amount and consistency of secretions
The presence of secretions not cleared by tracheal suction
Patient request
Equipment needed for cleaning of inner cannula
Labelled, dated designated bowl only to be used for inner cannula storage (changed daily)
Labelled, dated designated bowl only to be used for inner cannula cleaning (changed daily)
Labelled, dated bottle of sterile water only to be used for inner cannula cleaning (changed daily)
Tracheostomy cleaning swabs
Cleaning procedure
The inner cannula should be cleaned at least every 2 - 6 hours, or immediately if the patient looks to be in respiratory distress (as per First Responder's Emergency algorithm – see Appendix)
Wash hands and put on disposable plastic apron and gloves
Wear protective eyewear throughout the procedure
Assess whether the patient needs suction prior to this procedure and give suction as required as per guidelines (see 8.8)
N.B. In the case of an emergency where tube obstruction is the likely cause, the inner cannula should be removed, inspected and cleaned immediately
Stabilise the tracheostomy tube with one hand whilst removing the inner cannula by turning it anti-clockwise with the other. Place the dirty inner cannula into a designated bowl for cleaning.

Insert the spare clean inner cannula. Whilst stabilising the tracheostomy tube with one hand ensure the inner cannula is locked in place by turning it clockwise, replace humidification/ oxygen as appropriate
Cover the dirty inner cannula with sterile water and clean inside it using a tracheostomy cleaning swab.
Inner cannulae should not be cleaned or rinsed with tap water. Inner cannulae should also not be soaked
Gently tap any excess water from the clean cannula and leave in designated bowl for storage to dry.
Rinse the designated bowl for cleaning with sterile water and leave to dry. This bowl should not be used for any other purpose
Record the intervention on the tracheostomy care chart (see Appendix)
Wash your hands
Changing of stoma dressing and holder

This is a two-person technique for tracheostomy patients, one person must stabilise the tube in place whilst the other changes the dressing. Secretions often ooze out of the stoma causing wetness and irritation of the surrounding skin. Therefore, the stoma must be assessed at least every  hours for trauma, infection or inflammation and the dressing and holder should be replaced. The back of the neck should also be assessed at the same time for signs of rubbing and soreness from the tracheostomy holder/ tapes.
All findings should be documented on a wound assessment chart. Use of a broad soft tracheostomy holder should prevent skin damage at the back of the neck.

If the skin around the stoma becomes wet or irritated a barrier cream may be helpful to facilitate healing. Should this be the case the stoma dressing and holder will need to be changed more frequently.
Equipment needed:
Normal saline
Non adhesive dressing
Wound swab
Absorbent and non-adhesive dressing e.g.Lyofoam TM.
Tracheostomy tube holder
Light source
Procedure
Explain procedure to the patient;
Position patient to allow easy access to stoma
One nurse firmly secures the tube in place taking care not to push it in
The tracheostomy dressing and holder should be removed whilst the second person is securing the tracheostomy in place
observe skin for signs of infection, oedema or redness/excoriation;
Take swab if necessary;
Clean stoma with normal saline;
Apply clean non adhesive dressing shiny side to skin e.g., Lyofoam TM
Padded strapping should be cut to allow satisfactory securing of the tapes
Velcro tapes should be fastened comfortably but tight enough to allow only 2 fingers to fit between the tape and neck;
If the Velcro straps are consistently being tampered with or undone by the patient consult the tracheostomy team;
Changing tracheostomy tubes
Tracheostomy tubes may be changed:
1/ Electively
2/ In an emergency:
tube blockage
accidental decannulation
accidental displacement.
Elective changes
Recommendations for the frequency of changing tracheostomy tubes are unsupported by the literature. A European Economic Community Directive states

that surgically invasive devices intended for short-term use are in Class IIa and therefore normally intended for continuous use for not more than  days. In practice the frequency of tracheostomy tube change should be assessed on an individual patient basis taking into account:
a) For the First Change:
The procedure used to form the stoma.
- Surgical stomas are unlikely to be formed before  hours and percutaneous stomas before 7-10 days.

- Therefore it is recommended that a tracheostomy tube should not be electively changed until the tube has been in situ for 5 days post-surgical tracheostomy and 7-10 days post percutaneous tracheostomy formation.
- Earlier removal of the tube may result in loss of the stoma and formation of false passage.
- For head and neck cancer patients the head and neck team should be consulted prior to changing the tube.
b) For Subsequent Changes:
The design of the tracheostomy tube – It is thought to be good practice to change a single lumen tracheostomy every 7-14 days to prevent tube blockage with secretions
The purpose of the tracheostomy i.e. downsizing for weaning or fenestrated tube for speech.
Patient discomfort and trauma to the stoma site.
When planning a tracheostomy tube change always consider:
Is this an emergency or elective procedure?
Is this the best time to be doing this?
Does the patient have a potentially patent upper airway?
How formed is the stoma?
What are the alternatives to tracheostomy tube reinsertion?
Am I the best person to do this?
Is the patient adequately/appropriately prepared?
Have I got all the essential/appropriate equipment?
What will my primary and secondary oxygenation measures be?
Is there adequate support and do I need specialist input e.g. ENT/ MaxFax / Anaesthetics?
Coagulation status reviewed including timing of prescribed anticoagulation
Who should change the tube?

Only professionals who are competent in tracheostomy tube changes should perform this task. The highest risk tube change is one in a newly formed stoma or where there is airway or respiratory compromise. The grade of the professional changing the tube should therefore reflect the risk involved. Two persons should always be present and can be the following:
ITU Doctor (usually SpR or above) or Consultant
The on-call anaesthetic team
Trained and competent physiotherapists
Members of the ENT medical team
Trained and competent Nurses
The procedure for changing a tube

The type of tracheostomy tube used should be tailored to the patients' condition and will depend on various factors such as length of weaning time, original reason for tracheotomy and type of secretions.

This is a two-person technique, with one person supporting the tube and the patient and the other performing the change. In patients who are at risk of aspiration it is recommended that any enteral feed be stopped 3-4 hours prior to an elective procedure and the enteral tube aspirated immediately prior to the procedure. The procedure used for changing any tracheostomy tube will depend on the circumstances of that change.
There are two commonly used methods of changing tracheostomy tubes:

Guided exchange using an airway exchange catheter (recommended within critical care) – This is recommended for first or early changes and for patients with a high risk airway (including known difficult airway/ non-patent upper airway/ poorly formed stomas / limited respiratory reserve or potentially difficult primary oxygenation)
Blind exchange using an introducer / obturator – for patients with well-formed stomas and low risk airways
Equipment needed:
Sterile Wound Pack
Suture cutter
Appropriately sized tracheostomy tube and one a size smaller (if appropriate)
Tracheostomy tube holder
10ml syringe for cuffed tubes
Water-soluble lubricant
Sterile normal saline 0.9% sachet
Pre-cut slim line key hole dressing
Gloves, apron and protective eye wear
Tracheal dilators
Functioning suction unit and appropriately sized suction catheters
Stethoscope
Airway exchange catheter (for guided exchange)
Pulse oximeter
Oxygen mask
Oxygen supply
Resuscitation trolley
CO2 detector or waveform capnography
Slim-Fit Ambuscope available
Tracheostomy tube of the appropriate size and one a size smaller- in the majority of cases this will be a Tracoetwist plus™ tracheostomy tube.
Technique
Guided exchange using an airway exchange device (recommended for first exchange and high-risk airways)
Check emergency equipment is present and working
Two persons must be present
Consider stopping feed in accordance with local practice
Explain procedure to patient and gain patient consent if applicable
Ensure assistant is clear about what is expected of them
Wash hands
Wear disposable gloves, protective eyewear and plastic aprons throughout the procedure
Position patient in semi-recumbent position with neck slightly extended
Pre-oxygenate via Tracheostomy and apply oxygen to upper airway when patent, monitor saturations

Prepare equipment (Check tube cuff inflation of new tube if applicable, check inner cannula within existing tracheostomy tube and ensure a non-fenestrated inner cannula is in place, lubricate tracheostomy tube to be inserted)
Ask assistant to suction if required (oral and tracheal), remove old dressing and tapes and support the tube

Insert exchange device into trachea through tracheostomy tube e.g. Aintree intubation catheter or Cook Airway exchange catheter. For lower risk airways with more formed stomas a cut suction catheter may be considered.
Ask assistant to deflate the cuff
Remove old tube over exchange device
Insert new tube over exchange device. Consider the use of tracheal dilators if early tube change or small external stoma size.
Check for airflow through tube and Inflate cuff (if applicable)
Remove exchange device.
Identify presence of CO using CO2 detector / capnography and confirm correct
airway placement:
Where required reconnect to oxygen supply / ventilatory circuit
Dress and apply securing tapes
Observe the patient and their vital signs
Clear airway equipment according to trust policy
Document procedure in the case notes using printed label where available and check patient again. If using a fenestrated tube, place spare inner cannula in emergency pack and clearly label tube.
Blind exchange using an introducer / obturator
Check emergency equipment is present and working
Two persons must be present
Consider stopping feed in accordance with local practice
Explain procedure to patient and gain patient consent if applicable
Ensure assistant is clear about what is expected of them
Wash hands
Wear disposable gloves, protective eyewear and plastic aprons throughout the procedure
Position patient in semi-recumbent position with neck slightly extended
Consider pre-oxygenating the patient via Tracheostomy and apply oxygen to upper airway when patent, monitor saturations

Prepare equipment (Check tube cuff inflation of new tube if applicable, check inner cannula within existing tracheostomy tube and ensure a non-fenestrated inner cannula is in place if required, lubricate tracheostomy tube to be inserted & insert introducer)
Ask assistant to suction if required (oral and tracheal), remove old dressing and tapes and support the tube
Ensure cuff is deflated if present
Remove tube on expiration in a curved downward movement
Insert the clean tube with introducer in situ, using an up and over action
Remove the introducer and check for airflow through tube. Inflate the cuff where applicable.
Identify presence of CO using CO2 detector / capnography and confirm correct
airway placement:
Give oxygen where indicated via tracheostomy tube
Dress and apply securing tapes
Observe the patient and their vital signs
Clear airway equipment according to trust policy
Document procedure in the case notes using printed label where available and check patient again.
If unable to re-insert tube successfully or the patient becomes compromised
Maintain primary oxygenation via stoma and or nose and mouth where patent upper airway is present.
Call for help (on-call anaesthetist/ENT/Resus team) immediately and as appropriate to the situation.

Team to consider whether the patient is stable to attempt further tracheostomy insertion, whether upper airway intubation possible or preferred for definitive airway management in the current situation or whether it is safe for tracheostomy to remain removed.
If further attempts at tracheostomy insertion considered appropriate:
In the event of failed definitive airway management and oxygenation of patient not possible:
Communication

The presence of a tracheostomy can affect the patient's voice production. The loss of verbal communication can have a devastating effect on both the patient's communication effectiveness and his or her well-being.
It is the role of the Speech & Language Therapist (SLT) to assess and advise on an individual's ability to communicate their needs and feelings effectively.

It is recommended that patients who have communication difficulties due to organic, concomitant or psychogenic disorders should have access to an early, timely, responsive and appropriately skilled Speech and Language therapy service.
Communication may be assisted by the appropriate use of any of the following:
Mouthing words
Pen & paper
Alphabet boards, picture boards & phrase boards
Coded eye blinks
Electro-larynx
Electronic communication aids (when available)
Speaking valves/caps, where appropriate

Importance is placed on achieving the appropriate method of communication for the patient. Not all methods will suit all patients. The restoration of oral communication should be facilitated wherever possible, for example; using speaking valves, cuff deflation, fenestrated tubes at an appropriate time, whilst taking into account their individual medical needs.
Swallowing management

The presence of a tracheostomy tube can adversely affect swallowing in patients who previously had no dysphagia, and may further impair the swallowing function in those who already have neurological or mechanical disorders of swallowing.
The potential impact of a tracheostomy on swallowing function may include the following:
Reduction in the elevation and anterior movement of the larynx
Tracheal irritation at rest and during swallowing
Laryngeal stenosis
Reduced and uncoordinated laryngeal closure
Fixation of the trachea and compression of the oesophagus by the tracheostomy tube cuff
Reduced laryngeal sensitivity
Loss of protective reflexes
Insufficient, excessive or thick saliva production
Disruption of airway pressures
Reduction of airflow through the glottis
Blunting of reflexive cough

It is recommended that referral to a Speech and Language Therapist for swallow assessment should be considered for patients in whom oropharyngeal dysphagia is identified on screening, oral intake cannot be safely established or for patients who are at risk of dysphagia.

Where swallowing dysfunction is identified, appropriate investigations are undertaken by a SLT. A bedside assessment of a patient's swallowing ability will be made initially. Thereafter, specialised instrumental methods of swallowing assessment such as fibreoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing (FEES) and video fluoroscopy will be considered by the SLT with the medical team, as appropriate.
Following the assessment, recommendations regarding safety of swallow, patient positioning, swallow manoeuvres and textured diets will be advised.
All observations will be recorded in relevant notes. Any concerns should be brought to the attention of the SLT.
Care of tracheostomy tube with an inflated cuff

Patients breathing through a tracheostomy with an inflated cuff have no potential to breathe through their upper airway since the inflated cuff forms a seal between the lower and upper airways. In this instance the tracheostomy is the patient's only airway and this increases the nursing dependence of patients.

Patients who require an inflated cuff are at particularly high risk of complications and therefore require continuous airway monitoring by trained nursing staff. Patients who are nursed in isolation (single side room) should always have a dedicated competent airway trained nurse (one nurse to one patient). Patients with an inflated cuff nursed in an open ward bay require one nurse: two patients.

If a tracheostomy tube lumen is occluded by a decannulation cap or another device when the cuff is inflated the patient will not be able to breathe. In this situation the tracheostomy tube acts as a foreign body or obstruction within the trachea, and if the cap is not removed immediately (or the cuff deflated) respiratory arrest will occur.
NEVER CAP OFF A TRACHEOSTOMY WITH AN INFLATED CUFF

Before capping off or applying a speaking valve to a tracheostomy tube, ensure that the cuff is fully deflated; the tracheostomy is fenestrated, and it has a fenestrated inner cannula insitu. To deflate the cuff, attach a 10mL syringe to the pilot balloon and withdraw syringe until no more air can be aspirated.
The cuff should be deflated:
As part of the normal tracheostomy weaning/ upper airway rehabilitation process (see section 16)
If the patient is allowed to eat or drink, providing there is no risk of aspiration
To facilitate communication; a fenestrated inner cannula is inserted and speaking valve or decannulation cap is applied to the end of the tracheostomy tube

The pressure of the inflated cuff should be measured using a manometer and closely monitored. Excessive pressure may reduce perfusion to the tracheal mucosa resulting in mucosal ischaemia, necrosis and possible stenosis (narrowing of the airway).
A cuff manometer should be available on each ward designated to care for tracheostomy patients.
Checking the cuff pressure
Each shift and every time the cuff is re-inflated; check the cuff pressure using a cuff manometer
Cuff pressure should be maintained between 15 and 30 cm H2O (10 to  mm Hg) unless directed otherwise by medical staff
Explain to the patient the intention to measure the cuff pressure
Wash hands and put on a pair of clean gloves
Connect the pilot balloon to the manometer (an extension tube connector is optional). Depress the one-way valve by pushing the two together
Note the pressure indicated on the gauge and document on the airway care chart.
Disconnect and cap off the pilot balloon (not all models)
Take care not to deflate the balloon by accidentally depressing the automatic deflate button. If this does occur the cuff should be re-inflated and the pressure re-measured.
Wash the gauge with warm soapy water. Do not immerse.
Dry thoroughly after each use
Sub-glottic secretions drainage

Use of endotracheal tubes with a sub-glottic suction port to allow removal of secretions from above the cuff has been shown to reduce the incidence of ventilator associated pneumonia in critically ill patients. This is because the likelihood of aspiration of colonised oropharyngeal secretions past the cuff into the lower airways is reduced. Although there is no similar evidence to support the use of tracheostomy tubes with a sub-glottic suction port, it is reasonable to assume that regular removal of secretions from above the cuff should reduce leakage into the lungs. Recommended frequency of aspiration of secretions from the sub-glottic suction port is 4 hourly using a 10 mL syringe.
Weaning off the tracheostomy tube

Once the initial reason for the tracheostomy tube has resolved a plan for “weaning” off the tube can be made. Weaning may occur over a short period of time, for example with head and neck surgical patients who have intact airway protection mechanisms. For other patients with neurological deficits or severe muscle weakness a longer period of weaning is indicated. In these patients the weaning process should take the form of a programme designed to build muscle endurance where the work of breathing and effort required for coughing is gradually increased.
Weaning is commenced when:
The primary reason for the tracheostomy has resolved or been considered
The patient's condition is stable and improving
There are no signs of bronchopulmonary infection or excessive secretions
The weaning programme must be planned and clearly documented (Appendix 8). For complex patients advice should be sort from the tracheostomy team.

Good communication and documentation is essential to ensure smooth progression through the weaning process to decannulation. The programme of tube weaning will vary between ward areas but the order of the three weaning stages described below is set and should not vary. The patient should be nursed within maximum view of the nurse's station, with a call bell within easy reach and be sitting in an upright position. The physiotherapist and speech and language therapist are integral to the weaning process and should be involved with every patient at an early stage. Key stages of weaning are outlined below:
Stage 1 – Cuff deflation
The inflated cuff provides some protection against aspiration of orophryngeal secretions and therefore patients become unaccustomed to managing these and swallowing saliva.
A physiotherapist or competent person assesses cuff deflation tolerance, or the swallowing capability of the patient;
Give a full explanation of the procedure to the patient and carers, warn them that they may have a change in breathing sensation and may cough for a few minutes after the cuff is deflated.;
Attach pulse oximeter to patient;

Ask patient to cough and clear secretions, aspirate subglottic suction port (if available) and ensure patient's mouth is clear of secretions. This will minimise aspiration of secretions when the cuff is deflated. Caution with patients who have had intra-oral surgery;
With a fresh suction catheter suction either whilst gradually deflating the cuff, or deflate the cuff and immediately follow with suction;
Instruct the patient to practise swallowing their oral secretions

Closely monitor the patient for persistent coughing and or desaturation. This indicates that the patient may be aspirating their oral secretions or may have inadequate cough strength and excessive secretions. In both cases the cuff should be re-inflated using the minimum volume of air to reach the desired pressure. Refer to Speech and Language Therapy for issues with aspiration;

Some patients will require a slow increase in the amount of time the cuff is deflated due to muscle weakness whereas others may be able to tolerate 24 hours of cuff deflation at the first attempt. The aim is for the cuff to stay deflated all of the time if possible;
Once the patient can tolerate periods with the cuff deflated they may progress to vocalising and swallowing. A double lumen fenestrated tracheostomy tube is optimal for further weaning.
Stage 2 – Cuff deflation and tube occlusion with a gloved finger/ speaking valve
Remove the white/ plain inner cannula and deflate the cuff (stage 1 above).
Initially try ‘occluding' the tracheostomy tube with a gloved finger

Listen for airflow through the nose and mouth and monitor saturations during this procedure. If the patient's work of breathing increases, stridor is heard or saturations drop remove finger and do not wean further. The patient may require a smaller fenestrated tracheostomy tube before they are able to progress to stage
If tube occlusion with a gloved finger is well tolerated insert the “fenestrated” inner cannula and place the speaking valve over the tube opening.
Encourage throat clearing, expectoration, vocalisation and dry swallowing.
Remain with the patient to observe for signs of respiratory distress, a wet gurgly voice and dropping saturations when using a speaking valve for the first time.

Each patient is an individual and may require shorter or longer periods of stage 2 weaning. Some patients may take several days or weeks to achieve successful weaning. The aim is to increase tolerance to a minimum of 4 - 6 hours in the day. Some patients may require use of the speaking valve at night before decannulation is considered. Some patients can be dacannulated from a speaking valve (stage 2).

It is advised that the speaking valve is not used for very long periods because the patient is not receiving any humidification (i.e. breathing dry air through the valve). Remove the speaking valve for nebulisers as it can become sticky when
wet.
Stage 3 – Capping off (cuff deflated)

This is the final stage of tracheostomy weaning. With the cuff deflated and fenestrated inner cannula in place, a decannulation cap is applied. The tube is effectively blocked off by the cap. At this stage the patient is breathing around the tube through the normal route. As with stage 2, monitor the patient closely when progressing from a speaking valve to a cap. Stage 3 weaning is not a mandatory step for all patients with tracheostomies since some may be decannulated from a speaking valve (stage 2). Check with the tracheostomy team for advice.
Repeat stage 2 substituting speaking valve for a decannulation cap
Apply a fenestrated inner cannula and decannulation cap
The patient is allowed to build up tolerance with the decannulation cap
Patients with multiple problems will need to be capped off for short periods (e.g. 15 minutes) initially with careful monitoring and the time extended as per weaning plan

The period of time required before decannulation is considered will vary depending on many factors, including the reason for the insertion of the tracheostomy tube and the patient's general condition.
If the patient experiences respiratory distress during any stage of tracheostomy weaning, go back to the earlier step and refer to the tracheostomy team.
Always deflate the cuff before applying a speaking valve or decannulation cap (if in doubt seek advice from the tracheostomy team)
Decannulation of tracheostomy tube
Decannulation occurs when the tracheostomy is no longer required. Each patient will have been assessed carefully by the tracheostomy team, throughout the weaning process.
The weaning processes will have been completed and the removal of the tracheostomy will be a planned procedure.
The removal should occur early in the day.
Decannulation criteria
The tracheostomy tube should only be removed by those members of staff whom are deemed competent by the Trust.
Equipment needed:
Tracheal dilators
Spare unopened tracheostomy x 2, same size and I size smaller
Sterile wound pack
Wound swab
Normal sachet 0.9% saline
Oxygen face mask
Oxygen supply
Suction equipment
Gauze
Occlusive dressing
Protective eyewear
Pulse oximeter
Procedure:
Check all emergency equipment is present and working;
Two persons must be present;
Ensure the second person knows what is expected of them e.g. remove stitches, stabilise tube;
Position patient on the bed in semi recumbent position with the neck slightly extended;
Explain the procedure to the patient;
Wear protective eyewear throughout the decannulation process;
Wear gloves and apron;
Open sterile wound pack;
Give supplemental oxygen if deemed necessary;
Monitor oxygen saturations;
Perform oral and tracheal suction if necessary;
Ask the patient to take a deep breath. Remove tube in a curved downward movement while they are exhaling;
Observe stoma site for any signs of infection and consider swabbing
Clean stoma, dress with occlusive dressing;

Show the patient how to apply light pressure over the stoma site which will facilitate coughing and talking without displacement of the dressing. They may need to do this for a period of between 2 days to approximately 2 weeks depending on how quickly the stoma heals;
The patient should be encouraged to do hourly deep breathing exercises;
The stoma dressing should be changed twice per day, or more, depending on the amount of secretions;
The emergency equipment and tracheostomy box should be kept at the bedside for the next 24 hours;
Document decannulation in the patient's medical notes;

The most common reasons for decannulation failure include failure to clear secretions, increased work of breathing and damage to the trachea e.g. granuloma, tracheomalacia. Therefore, patients should be observed for signs of respiratory distress. The patient should have continual monitoring and respiratory rate and oxygen saturations observations recorded every 15 minutes for the first 4 hours; then if the patient is stable, 4 hourly over the next 24 hours
Ensure the patient has the call bell within reach and can be observed
Emergencies

In case of any breathing problems with a patient with a front of neck airway follow the First responder emergency algorithm (see Appendix). This should be placed above the patient's bedhead in full view. For secondary responders the Trust follows the National Tracheostomy Safety Project algorithm for tracheostomy and laryngectomy emergencies (see Appendix). These should be attached to the difficult airway trolley in each ward area.
Preparing a patient with a front of neck airway for discharge

A plan for safe discharge of a patient with a front of neck airway must be in place. Before a patient can be discharged it is important to identify who will be responsible for  the  day  to  day  care  of  the  tracheostomy/  laryngectomy  tube  and  stoma. Preparing a patient with a front of neck airway for discharge home or to a care home must involve the following steps:
Training and education in tube and stoma care for the patient and/ or carers
Completion of the discharge checklist (see Appendices  and 11) by the patient/ carer and signed off by the ward team looking after the patient
Provision for the supply of the required equipment and consumables for management of the patient's tube and stoma at home
Training the patient/ carer for what they should do in an emergency.
Notify the local ambulance service prior to discharge of a neck breather living in the community and “text 999 service” set up as appropriate
Make arrangements for ongoing tube changes and weaning from the tube (where appropriate)
Issue the Tracheostomy Passport to the patient and advise them to carry it with them to all hospital appointments
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitori ng report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Availability of fully stocked emergency equipment (Blue Box)
Front of Neck Airway nominated Wards
Availability of completed bed head signage
Front of Neck Airway nominated Wards

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Tracheostomy team which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Tracheostomy nominated wards of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix 12)

Competency for care of a patient with a tracheostomy or laryngectomy
Staff Name –
Date tracheostomy training attended – Ward –
Mentor -
These competency documents are designed to be used in conjunction with the generic core competency document.
Competence in caring for a patient with a front of neck airway is achieved by successful completion of theoretical questions and demonstration of practical skills as outlined in this document.
Competency 1 – Front of neck airway theory

table_items.text: Understands the use and can locate bed head signage for adjusted airway patients
Can gather the paperwork needed for an adjusted airway patient and understands how to complete it
Demonstrates an understanding of the importance of accurate documentation
Demonstrates the ability to take a sputum sample from an adjusted airway patient
Can give rationale for the use of supplemented humidification in an adjusted airway patient

Can adjust the settings on a heated humidification machine
Can discuss what to do in an adjusted airway emergency

Describes what to do if staffing levels fall below requirements
Can perform an accurate assessment of a patient with an adjusted airway
Has attended the Trusts tracheostomy study day

Demonstrates an understanding of what a tracheostomy is

Describes the differences between a surgical and a percutaneous tracheostomy
Describes the use of rescue sutures

Describes the differences between a fenestrated and non-fenestrated inner tube and explains when each should be used
Demonstrates an understanding of why a tracheostomy may have a cuff and describes its use

Describes how to use a subglottic suction port and its benefits
Demonstrates the ability to change a tracheostomy inner tube and describes how to store it

Can demonstrate how to change a tracheostomy dressing
Can demonstrate how to change tracheostomy tapes and the safety measures in place
Can discuss the reasons for decannulation of a tracheostomy

Demonstrates an understanding of why a laryngectomy needs humidification at all times

data.text: Competency 2 – Tracheostomy/ Laryngectomy Care practical skills

For staff new to front of neck airway management, each skill is to be observed and signed/ dated  times by an airway competent nurse/ physiotherapist. The airway trainee should be able to perform and discuss the indications for each airway procedure or piece of equipment in the blue box. The trainee can be deemed to be competent once 10 satisfactory observations are completed.
Please keep this record to provide evidence of your airway competence and a reminder for when you will need to attend tracheostomy update session (every 2 years).

table_items.text: Stoma cleaning, dressing and tapes change
Equipment Checklist completed and demonstrates knowledge of each piece of equipment in box

Appendix 10: Tracheostomy discharge checklist
Mid and South Essex Tracheostomy Discharge Guidelines.

Patients who are discharged from an acute hospital with a tracheostomy tube have limited support in the community. Therefore, they or/and their carers must be trained on the ward to feel confident in the day-to-day care and management of their tracheostomy tube. Planning their discharge is a complex process, involving close liaison with the patient's community team and ensuring the right specialist equipment is provided for the patient.

This document lays out the core skills required by the patient and/or the carer prior to discharge from hospital. It also lists the essential equipment which must be provided and ordered for the patient. This is to ensure as safe a discharge as possible from hospital.
Ward nurse's should be assigned to the duty of ensuring the guidelines are carried out and signed off when the patient and/or the carer feel confident, ensuring this is completed prior to discharge.

The Head and Neck CNS's will be responsible for arranging suction machines with the district nurses and arranging ongoing consumables, registering the patient with the SMS 999 service and Ambulance special information form (neck breathing register), as well as registering the tracheostomy patients with companies who supply ongoing equipment. The CNS will also refer the patient to the district nurses on discharge (Mon-Fri). District nurses may require training.
The ward team should supply the patient with enough equipment for 2weeks on discharge to allow the district nursing teams to have sufficient time to re-order the necessary equipment.
Discharge letters are to be sent by the ward staff or ward clerk to the patients local CNS on day of discharge so they are aware of the discharge (e-mails with contact details in appendix).
Contents of pack:
1: Skills required by patient and/or carer prior to discharge, these skills should be signed off and filed in the patients' medical records on discharge and a copy should be given to the patient.
2: A list of essential tracheostomy equipment required for home care and where to order the equipment from. The CNS is to register patient with Fittleworth and place the first order.
3: Diagram of tracheostomy anatomy (to be used with the patient and/or carer for education).
4: Tracheostomy emergency guidelines (to be covered with the patient and/or carer prior to discharge, and for the patient to keep at home).
5: Contact telephone numbers and e-mails for once the patient has been discharged from the ward. Appendix's:
1: 999 SMS leaflet
2: Ambulance registers for neck breather's form

table_items.text: Tracheostomy skills required before discharge from hospital.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate understanding of basic knowledge of altered airway and understand limitations of patient's upper airway.
Patient and/or carer can identify the types and parts of the tube they possess.
Patient and/or carer able to demonstrate understanding of the importance of stoma cleaning and frequency, and able to perform this (daily, or more if sections are coming from stoma).
Patient and/or carer able to state possible signs of skin damage or infection at the stoma site.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate understanding of the importance of inner tube cleaning and frequency.
Patient and/or carer show confidence in changing the inner tube.
Patient and/or carer understand the different types of inner tube and when they should be used (fenestrated - voicing, plain- suctioning).
Patient and/or carer demonstrate confidence in cleaning the inner tube using tracheostomy swabs and sterile water (the patient can sue cooled boiled water at home).
Patient and/or carer demonstrate an understanding of the importance of dressing care and frequency of changes (daily, or if soiled).
Patient and/or carer demonstrate confidence in changing the dressing.
Patient and/or carer demonstrates they understand the importance of having two people to change the tracheostomy tapes (district nurses can be involved).
Patient and/or carer advised that the tapes should be changed weekly at a minimum.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate awareness of the indications for suctioning.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate awareness of tracheal and oral suctioning.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate an understanding of the correct inner tube to use when suctioning.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate an effective deep suction technique and when to use deep suction.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate awareness of when deep suction is required and methods to avoid it (changing inner tube and nebulising to encourage secretion clearing).
Patient and/or carer have been explained the rationale for needing humidification when using a tracheostomy.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate ability to change HME device.
Patient and/or carer able to set up and give a nebuliser and demonstrate understanding of the importance of this.
Patient and or carer demonstrate ability to clean nebuliser chamber following a nebuliser.
Patient and/or carer are aware of what constitutes an emergency.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate an understanding of indications of a blocked tube.
Patient and/or carer indicate what to do if the tube becomes blocked.
Patient and or carer know what to do if the tracheostomy tube becomes displaced.
Patient and/or carer is aware of the SMS 999 service and that they will be registered with the ambulance service neck breathing register.

data.text: Emergency details.

If the tracheostomy tube is blocked, remove the inner tube and replace. If this does not clear the blockage, attempt to pass a suction catheter through the tracheostomy. If you cannot pass a suction catheter call . Explain that ……………………………….. Is a neck breather and their tracheostomy is occluded, you need urgent assistance.

If the tracheostomy tube has fallen out, attempt to replace it ONCE. If unsuccessful call 999 explain the situation and place the dilators in the stoma as shown on the ward, ensure the neck is extended to assist in opening the airway. If replacement is successful, consider medical help to confirm everything is ok and ensure the neck tapes are tight.
Information for emergency services:
They are expected to only have…………………………………………….... upper airway. The patient should have tracheal dilators and spare tracheostomy tubes.
The patients usual tracheostomy is………………………………………………………………………….. one size smaller is……………………………………………………………………………
If in doubt apply oxygen to the face and neck stoma. Contact numbers:

Appendix 11: Laryngectomy discharge checklist
Mid and South Essex Laryngectomy Discharge Guidelines.

Patients who are discharged from an acute hospital following a laryngectomy have limited support in the community. Therefore, they and/or their carers must be trained on the ward to feel confident in the day-to-day care and management of their laryngectomy stoma. Planning their discharge is a complex process, involving close liaison with the patient's local CNS and Speech therapy team and ensuring the right specialist equipment is provided for the patient.

This document lays out the core skills required by the patient and/or the carer prior to discharge from hospital. It also lists the essential equipment which must be provided and ordered for the patient. This is to ensure as safe a discharge as possible from hospital.
Ward nurses should be assigned to the duty of ensuring the guidelines are carried out and signed off when the patient and/or the carer feel confident, ensuring this is completed prior to discharge.

The Head and Neck CNS's will be responsible for registering the patient with the SMS 999 service and Ambulance special information form (neck breathing register). The Head and Neck CNS will also arrange (on rare occasions) suction machines with the district nurses.

District nurses may require training, and their support for these patients is limited. If we feel as a team that a district nurse is required, the CNS will liaise with the District nurse to ensure that training has been arranged prior to discharge.

The ward team should supply the patient with enough equipment for 2 weeks on discharge to allow the Speech and Language team to request a prescription with the GP and for the prescription companies or district nursing teams to have sufficient time to re-order and deliver the necessary equipment.
Discharge letters are to be sent by the ward staff or ward clerk to the patients local CNS on day of discharge so they are aware of the discharge (e-mails with contact details in appendix).
Contents of pack:
1: Skills required by patient and/or carer prior to discharge, these skills should be signed off and filed in the patients' medical records on discharge and a copy should be given to the patient.
2: A list of essential laryngectomy equipment required for home and where to order the equipment from. The SLT is to register patient with Fittleworth or Countrywide.
3: Diagram of laryngectomy anatomy (to be used with the patient and/or carer for education).
4: Laryngectomy emergency guidelines (to be covered with the patient and/or carer prior to discharge, and for the patient to keep at home).
5: Contact telephone numbers and e-mails for once the patient has been discharged from the ward.
Appendices:
1: 999 SMS leaflet
2: Ambulance registers for neck breather's form

table_items.text: Laryngectomy skills required before discharge from hospital.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate understanding of basic knowledge of altered airway and understand the changes to the patient's airway.

Patient and/or carer able to demonstrate understanding of the importance of stoma cleaning and frequency with which it needs to be done, (daily, or more if sections are coming from stoma) and able to perform this.
Patient and/or carer able to state possible signs of skin damage or infection at the stoma site.
Patient and/or carer aware of the need to de-crust the stoma on a regular basis and are able to carry this out.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate understanding of the importance of tube cleaning and frequency of cleaning needed (if worn).
Patient and/or carer show confidence in removing and replacing the laryngectomy tube including applying and fastening of trachy ties.
Patient and/or carer able to discuss the importance of Larry tube cleaning.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate awareness of the indications for secretion clearance.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate awareness of when the patient needs to cough to clear secretions.
Patient and/or carer able to identify when secretions are thicker and how to manage these.
Patient and/or carer is able to clear secretions away from the stoma with only a tissue, and/or forceps without resorting to suction.
Patient and/or carer have been explained the rationale for the importance of humidification.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate ability to change humidification devices (HME, BIB, NEB).
Patient and/or carer able to set up and give a nebuliser and demonstrate understanding of the importance of this.
Patient and or carer demonstrate ability to clean nebuliser chamber following a nebuliser.
Patient and/or carer are aware of what constitutes an emergency. (mucus plug, foreign object in stoma)
Patient and/or carer demonstrate an understanding of indications of a blocked laryngectomy tube.
Patient and/or carer indicate what to do if the stoma becomes blocked.
Patient and/or carer is aware of the SMS 999 service and that they will be registered with the ambulance service neck breathing register.
Patient and/or carer are aware of how the valve works.
Patient is able to use the speaking valve.
Patient and/or carer demonstrate how to safely clean the speech valve.
Patient and/or carer can discuss what to do if the valve starts to leak and have the details of who to contact at their local centre.
Patient and/or carer are aware of who to contact if the valve is in place but voice is lost.
Patient and/or carer know what to do if the valve is displaced

data.text: Essential laryngectomy equipment to be obtained prior to discharge from hospital (2pages).

table_items.text: Patient to purchase. Available in Argos, Boots or any large pharmacy.
Show the patient how to use it when they bring it in
1 length (discuss with the patient how close the plug socket is to where they will be nebulising).
Fittleworth/SLT depending on type of tube
Unless worn, please ensure that any larry tubes used by patient at any time on the ward are packed to go with them for possible future use.
Future discussion between SLT and Patient.
For cleaning inside the lary tube
For lubrication of larry tube pre insertion
Pack what has been used on the ward
To use on skin around the stoma
Humidification if using lary tube or base plates
At least 20 cassettes. 15 Xtramoist 5 Xtraflow (or as available)
At least 4. Can be large or small (Patient preference)
LA BUP 0001 White (other colours are available)

data.text: Emergency details.

If the laryngectomy is blocked, remove any obvious plugs and lary tube if wearing one. If this does not clear the blockage place a nebuliser on and call 999. Explain that ……………………………….. Is a neck breather and their laryngectomy is occluded, you need urgent assistance.
Information for emergency services:

………………………………………… Has a laryngectomy and can only breathe via their neck stoma they do not have an upper airway connected to the nose or mouth. Look into the stoma to see if there is anything that can be removed.

What are you proposing to change?

Update references. Add more detail to changing tracheostomy tubes (according to national guidance) Add the discharge checklist to the appendices. Change from MEHT to MSE template Author to complete table in full
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
To update practice according to national guidance For better communication and safer practice
Who benefits from this change and how?
Staff and patients- To ensure safer practice and for staff training
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
No- this guideline have been updated according to evidence base and national guidance
